<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3 (P3)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 589, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 613, 92]]<|/det|>
Using the substitution \(u = \mathrm{e}^{x}\), or otherwise, solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 100, 554, 119]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{e}^{x} = 1 + 6\mathrm{e}^{-x},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 125, 524, 144]]<|/det|>
giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 126, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 172, 97, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 171, 437, 191]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 198, 623, 217]]<|/det|>
\[x = 3(1 + \sin^{2}t),\quad y = 2\cos^{3}t.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 643, 255]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) in terms of \(t\), simplifying your answer as far as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 284, 97, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 282, 900, 303]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(x^{4} + 3x^{3} + ax + 3\) is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). It is given that \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divisible by \(x^{2} - x + 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 316, 153, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 316, 316, 333]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 346, 153, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 345, 687, 364]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) has this value, find the real roots of the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 346, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 392, 96, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 601, 411]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(\theta\) are related by the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 420, 603, 450]]<|/det|>
\[\sin 2\theta \frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}\theta} = (x + 1)\cos 2\theta ,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
where \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi\). When \(\theta = \frac{1}{12}\pi\), \(x = 0\). Solve the differential equation, obtaining an expression for \(x\) in terms of \(\theta\), and simplifying your answer as far as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 476, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 521, 96, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 521, 151, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 521, 650, 540]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 546, 561, 567]]<|/det|>
\[\sec x = 3 - \frac{1}{2} x^{2},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 574, 620, 594]]<|/det|>
where \(x\) is in radians, has a root in the interval \(0 < x < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 607, 151, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 607, 620, 625]]<|/det|>
Verify by calculation that this root lies between 1 and 1.4.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 607, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 637, 153, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 637, 520, 656]]<|/det|>
Show that this root also satisfies the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 663, 576, 694]]<|/det|>
\[x = \cos^{-1}\Big(\frac{2}{6 - x^{2}}\Big).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 670, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 714, 151, 732]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 713, 920, 747]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula based on the equation in part (iii) to determine the root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 730, 920, 747]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 777, 96, 794]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 776, 920, 810]]<|/det|>
(i) Express \(\cos x + 3 \sin x\) in the form \(R \cos (x - \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^\circ < \alpha < 90^\circ\), giving the exact value of \(R\) and the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 792, 920, 811]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 823, 153, 841]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 822, 670, 841]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\cos 2\theta + 3\sin 2\theta = 2\), for \(0^\circ < \theta < 90^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 823, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
With respect to the origin \(O\), the position vectors of two points \(A\) and \(B\) are given by \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = 3\mathbf{i} + 4\mathbf{j}\). The point \(P\) lies on the line through \(A\) and \(B\), and \(\overrightarrow{AP} = \lambda \overrightarrow{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 127, 154, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 125, 561, 147]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\overrightarrow{OP} = (1 + 2\lambda)\mathbf{i} + (2 + 2\lambda)\mathbf{j} + (2 - 2\lambda)\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 145]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 160, 154, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 159, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
By equating expressions for \(\cos AOP\) and \(\cos BOP\) in terms of \(\lambda\) , find the value of \(\lambda\) for which \(OP\) bisects the angle \(AOB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 178, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 207, 151, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 205, 599, 225]]<|/det|>
When \(\lambda\) has this value, verify that \(AP:PB = OA:OB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 207, 920, 225]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 262, 96, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 252, 331, 289]]<|/det|>
Let \(\operatorname {f}(x) = \frac{12 + 8x - x^2}{(2 - x)(4 + x^2)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 306, 156, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 301, 485, 336]]<|/det|>
Express \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) in the form \(\frac{A}{2 - x} + \frac{Bx + C}{4 + x^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 307, 920, 326]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 350, 153, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 348, 400, 384]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\int_{0}^{1} \mathrm{f}(x) \mathrm{~d}x = \ln \left(\frac{25}{2}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 409, 96, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 415, 751, 644]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 668, 653, 687]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = x^{2} \ln x\) and its minimum point \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 700, 156, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 700, 526, 718]]<|/det|>
Find the exact values of the coordinates of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 700, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 731, 153, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 730, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the area of the shaded region bounded by the curve, the \(x\)-axis and the line \(x = \mathrm{e}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 744, 920, 763]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 791, 106, 810]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 791, 146, 810]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 791, 920, 825]]<|/det|>
Showing your working, find the two square roots of the complex number \(1 - (2\sqrt{6})\mathrm{i}\). Give your answers in the form \(x + \mathrm{i}y\), where \(x\) and \(y\) are exact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 839, 146, 856]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 838, 920, 871]]<|/det|>
On a sketch of an Argand diagram, shade the region whose points represent the complex numbers \(z\) which satisfy the inequality \(|z - 3\mathrm{i}|\leqslant 2\). Find the greatest value of \(\arg z\) for points in this region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 870, 920, 887]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
